name: 李旻璁
objective:
This course focuses on understanding the algorithms behind programming solutions rather than the syntax of any specific programming language. Students will learn how to conceptualize, develop, and implement algorithms to solve engineering problems using a dual-language approach. Fortran will be used to introduce algorithmic fundamentals, while Python—generated and explored through ChatGPT—will demonstrate how logical structures can be adapted across languages.

A key emphasis of this course is cultivating literacy in using Generative AI tools, especially ChatGPT, for programming. Students will learn how to prompt ChatGPT effectively, interpret and critique AI-generated code, and use it as a tool to accelerate their understanding of computational thinking. The course aims to empower students to confidently build adaptable, reliable solutions for engineering applications, especially those involving data analysis, simulation, and visualization.
schedule:
Part I: Foundations and Tools (Weeks 1–3)
Introduction to programming and ChatGPT as a GenAI assistant
Basic Linux operations, shell usage, and the vim editor
Setting up compilers and interpreters; visualization with gnuplot
Role of spreadsheets (Excel) in conceptual planning

Part II: Programming Concepts with Fortran (Weeks 4–10)
Input/Output (I/O) fundamentals
Variable declaration and data types
Mathematical operations and built-in functions
Control structures: loops (do), conditionals (if)
File operations and array handling
Subroutines and modules
Introduction to random number generation
* During these sessions, Python equivalents will be generated using ChatGPT to reinforce the portability of algorithmic thinking.

Part III: Applied Algorithms and Visualization (Weeks 11–16)
Sorting algorithms and data organization
Statistical analysis and data interpretation
Probability functions and histogram plotting
Regression modeling and trend analysis
Generating random walk trajectories and visualizing with VMD
Simulating self-assembly and analyzing aggregate structures
scorePolicy:
Class Participation (Zuvio attendance and Q&A) 20%
In-Class Exercises (hands-on programming tasks) 40%
Final Project Report (individual or group-based) 40%

There are no midterm or final exams. Attendance is mandatory, and students are expected to actively participate in in-class discussions and exercises.
materials: Instructor-prepared materials will be used throughout the course.
